column1: #Text=The oil expressed from the bitter or sweet almond.

#Text=Used in preparing Oleum Phosphoratum, Unguenhim Cetacei,
#Text=Uncjuentum Ilesince, and Unguenhm, Simplex, and the preparations containing it.
#Text=The oil distilled in Britain from dill fruit.
#Text=Colour pale yellow, odour pungent, taste hot and sweetish.

#Text=Colourless or very pale yellow ; with the odour of the fruit,

#Text=The oil distilled in Britain from chamomile flowers.
#Text=Pale blue or greenish-blue, but gradually becoming yellowish brown ; with the peculiar aromatic taste and odour of the

#Text=with a strong penetrating agreeable camphoraceous odour, and a

#Text=The oil distilled in Britain from caraway fruit.

#Text=The oil distilled in Britain from cloves.
#Text=Colourless or pale yellow when recent, but gradually becoming

#Text=Used in preparing Confectio Scammonii, Pilula Colocynthidis Composita, and Pilula Colocynthidis et Hyoscyami.
#Text=Yellowish when recent, but gradually becoming cherry-red,
#Text=having the odour and taste of cinnamon bark.

#Text=somewhat rancid, disagreeable odour, and an oily acrid taste.

#Text=The oil distilled in Britain from the flowers of Lavandula vera.

#Text=Used in preparing Linimentum Patassii Iodidi cum Sapone
#Text=The oil expressed in Britain without heat from linseed.
#Text=Viscid, yellow, with a faint odour, and bland oleaginous
#Text=It gradually thickens by exposure to the air.
#Text=The oil distilled in Britain from fresh flowering peppermint,
#Text=Colourless, pale yellow, or greenish-yellow when recent, but
#Text=becoming gradually thicker and reddish by age, with the odour
#Text=of peppermint, and a strong penetrating aromatic taste, followed
#Text=by a sensation of coldness in the mouth.
